doc.source_uri: 2025-08-29/JPM International Market Intelligence Morning BriefingJPM International Market Intelligence Morning Briefing_2025-08-29

passages.text: MKT INTEL VIEWS: NVDA saw modest selling pressure, but it left the AI trade intact as the rest of the tech complex traded very well and with broad gains. The SPX delivered a new ATH but the equal- weight version of the index was essentially unchanged. A solid 2Q GDP revision did not really help the broadening trade but today's PCE could be different. Brazil was also in the spotlight yesterday, with equities notably outperforming the US and global peers. This comes as the presidential elections near into focus, with moves driven by a poll release – which revealed that President Lula's popularity wavered in August, and that the tariff- driven spike in approval ratings was short lived.

In Europe, yesterday's data showed stability and were in line with the signal from the PMI of trend- like growth while ECB minutes keep Sep ECB meeting a low vol event. Odds of a ceasefire did not react much to the news that Putin and Zelenskiy aren't going to meet. Focus remains on:

- France. We published desk thoughts on Weds and JPM Research is now out with a scenario analysis (table below). Overall, fiscal outcomes are expected to remain in line with forecasts, even in a relative majority RN government. The main risks to this are if Macron resigns (but probability very low at 5%) or if a Left coalition forms. Taken together, the recent repricing in French spreads seems broadly fair. On FX, the transmission of political risk should be limited given bounded fiscal outcomes. While the team remains bullish EUR/USD, fair value has now converged to market levels, so EUR/CHF could be a better expression if spreads continue to widen.- The topic of the internal rotation. As we noted yesterday, Luxury is probably the most debated theme as investors focus on: a) the dislocations to China rally (but with reservations, given driver of A shares has been liquidity, not macro surprises); b) increasing confidence on the strength of US consumer (visible in high frequency proxies and with tailwinds from Stock/Crypto wealth effects); and c) positioning. That said, some question the sustainability of the move as it happens amid some momentum unwind. Our Asia Consumer Spec sales notes the next catalyst could come from EU Luxury companies updating investors on latest news/thoughts in September.

Meanwhile, the recent rally in China onshore has been in focus over the past weeks. Nikos writes that this was supported by domestic retail margin traders, inflows from foreign retail investors, as well as

speculative investors via CSI 300 futures contracts. The key question now is how much farther this extends, given speed and a macro backdrop in China that remains mixed. Reports emphasize the role of retail investors given significant accumulated savings and signs of rotation out of deposit accounts and into equities while research notes the ratio of margin purchases as share of the free float in the onshore Chinese equity market still remains below the local peak of \(3.8\%\) in early April and well below the record high of \(6.4\%\) in 2015. Our Local Spec Sales, however, flags yesterday saw a record \(\mathsf{HK}\$ 20.4bn\) of SB outflows, and there is a case for some sideways consolidation over the next few months, even if the fundamental story remains positive. Those looking to chase, might consider options.

In terms of catalysts, today we are watching, BABA FQ1 earnings, Jul PCE and hearing of the Lisa Cook termination case. Over the weekend, watch China PMIs and Putin- Xi- Modi meeting in Tianjin to discuss energy ties.
OVERNIGHT RECAP (link)

FRENCH POLITICS: Note considers the options after the no confidence vote and their fiscal implications: Fiscal outcomes overall would be in line with our deficit forecast; If the new PM option is politically unstable, Macron could call a snap election - but fiscal implications likely to remain in line. Overall transmission to FX should be limited, stay bullish EUR/USD.

ECB MINUTES: ECB's July minutes sounded slightly more open- minded about the possibility of a further rate cut than the impression Lagarde gave at the press conference. However, combined with comments and "sources" articles since then, the impression remains that the ECB will be on hold in September and that it needs a push to ease after that.

FLOWS & LIQUIDITY: The recent rally in Chinese onshore equities has been supported by domestic retail margin traders, inflows from foreign retail investors, as well as speculative investors via CSI 300 futures contracts. But the ratio of margin purchases as share of the free float still stands below the local peak and record high.

US GDP: Q2 revised higher up from \(3.0\% q / q\) saar to \(3.3\%\) , which reflected upward revisions to consumption and nonresidential business fixed investment. The notable thing here was that pre- tax corporate profits rebounded in 2Q despite the rise in tariff charges.

TOKYO CPI: While government subsidies on utility charges and the suppression of increases in other public charges are restraining the acceleration of inflation, the momentum in other prices remains robust and is broadening.

RETAIL RADAR: Retail net purchased \(\) 6.3\(B over the past week,\) \sim \$2B\(above the levels observed over the past month and in line with the weekly YTD average of\) \ \(6.5B\) . Following a period of subdued

activity, last Friday marked a renewed surge of interest from retail investors. retail investors also became net buyers of single stocks after rehanging net sellers for an entire month, fueled by Tech. TODAY'S CATALYSTS: a) GE Retail Sales, Employment, CPI; FR CPI, GDP; b) US Personal Income & Spending, PCE, Wholesale & Retail Inventories, UMich F; c) Japan Tokyo Aug CPI, Jul Unemployment, Retail Sales, Housing Starts; India 2Q GDP; Phils, Thailand Jul Trade; South Korea Jul IP d) Fed's Water speaks; e) ECB 1Y & 3Y Expectations; f) The US to end its "de minimis" tariff exemption; g) EARNINGS: ASIA: BABA, BYD, ICBC, ABC, CCB, BOC, CMB, PSB, Shenhua Energy

POSITION PROXY FOR CHINESE EQUITY FUTURES
Source: Bloomberg Finance L.P., J.P. Morgan Flows & Liquidity.

- EU: European Equities closed mixed (UKX -0.4%, SX5E 0.1%, SXXP -0.2%) with NVDA earnings doing little to boost global risk sentiment. But AI related themes, incl. Electrification & Power and Semis, were the best performing thematics in Europe. MOMO Shorts continued to perform well: Luxury extended this week's gains, Autos rallied on positive sector data and Basic Resources rose in line with Iron Ore. EU rates closed generally lower (UK 2Y -3bps, 10Y -4bps, GE 2Y 2bps, 10Y -1bps).

- US: US Equities closed higher (SPX 0.3%, NDX 0.6%, RTY 0.2%), despite NVDA's unexciting Q2 print. While the stock closed lower on the day (-0.8%), it was well off post-result lows (-5%). TMT Crowded Longs and AI Leaders performed well, but it was interesting that Software outperformed Semis. But overall, this helped MOMO come back (1.9%) Focus was also on the Retail sector (-0.7%), given a flurry of reporting. US rates closed mixed (2Y 2bps, 10Y -3bps).

- Asia: APAC stocks are mixed (NKY -0.2%, HSI 1%, CSI 300 0.9%) with all eyes on BABA reporting today. Japan underperformed on macro data – while Tokyo CPI printed in line, retail sales disappointed. In HK, main focus is BABA earnings later today, with HSTECH rallying (1.1%). China onshore also trades higher, with sentiment boosted after The State Council issued guidelines on boosting renovation of urban villages, vowing to adopt new fiscal and financial policy tools to attract private capital in urban construction. EU and US futures are lower (SX5E flat, SPX -0.1%).
Report: Weekly Wrap | Set-up into Jackson Hole / NVDA...Tech Elevated, Broader US Positioning Not, but Modest Pullback Could Still Play Out (Aug 22nd)

Summary: Heading into the key events over the next week, we see some signs that positioning levels are elevated. At the same time, sentiment, recent flows, and market rotations (e.g. cyc/def, beta, and momentum reversals) suggest a more risk- off tone has started to creep in.

Looking at past rebounds from prior lows in our US TPM Level (i.e. lows of - 0.8z or below), the current SPX rebound is on par with some of the best we've seen in the past; however, there's often been a pullback of around \(5 - 8\%\) over the next 1.5 months. This may not start over the next week, but history suggests it wouldn't be surprising if it were to occur soon.

In addition, while the level of aggregate positioning isn't that high in absolute terms (currently only \(+0.2z\) ), this is actually fairly similar to the past. Or looked at differently, when we index the level of positioning to the prior lows, the increase from lows has been about on par with past events.

Going back to what was mentioned earlier, there are some signs that positioning levels are a bit high: HF net leverage (near YTD highs), CTA positioning, Asset Mgr positioning in US Eq. futures, and buying of US stocks by EU investors per TIC data.
Despite some of the internal market volatility over the past couple weeks, HF performance has been pretty muted (average \(+0.7\%\) MTD globally with fairly neutral long- short spreads).

Interestingly, despite the drop in US Momentum's performance, we have not seen a similar drawdown in the most crowded HF stocks (on a long- short basis)...this is similar to the 2H20 through 2021 period. It's too early to tell if this reduced correlation will persist as medium term returns (i.e. 20d rolling returns) still appear closely linked and the correlation between HF crowding and Momentum has been persistently positive since early 2024.

On the sector front, Semis/Mag7 will be in focus next week as well. Overall we see Mag7 positioning remaining elevated as it has been over the past few weeks (i.e., L/S ratio still at \(94^{\text{th}}\) %- tile and net exposure at \(+2z\) ). Semis positioning in N. America also remains around historical highs and it's notable that Info Tech has been the most net bought sector by HFs over the past 5d with Semis and Software both bought. In contrast broader Cyclicals were mostly sold in the past week.

Outside the US, China local stocks have been the most bought in the past week, while HK have been most sold. In addition, the China Anti- Involution theme continues to be in focus and we've seen HF positioning pick up in the China stock beneficiaries basket (JPCHSCBF).

In Europe, HFs were initially adding to shorts this month, but flows have recently started to flip a bit more positively. Notably, despite the recent weakness in EU Defence (JPEUDEFN), we're starting to see HFs come back to the group as longs get added back. In addition, EU Defence Secondary Winners remains a theme with strong HF flows and elevated positioning (L/S ratio at \(96^{\text{th}}\) %- tile since 2018).
Andrew Tyler | Federico Manicardi | Ellen Wang | Victoria Campos

Data Assets & Alpha – delivering high frequency J. P. Morgan trading data and associated insights from the Market, Data and Positioning Intelligence teams. Available through written product on JP Morgan Markets, conference calls & podcasts via platforms including Apple, Google and Spotify, and data feeds via the DataQuery application & Fusion platform.

To sign up to this content or other written pieces from the Data Assets & Alpha Group, visit jpmm.com, select My Homepage => My Research Subscriptions => Markets Insights. You can then sign up to our content by Author or Publication.
High frequency data- driven market insights and trade ideas leveraging macro, fundamental and political inputs
Proprietary data and signals from our industry- leading Markets business, including equity signals, retail sentiment and volatility marks

Proprietary positioning and flows- based data and analysis, based on the J. P. Morgan Prime book, Retail investor and ETF flows, among other sources. Data sets including positioning, flows, crowding, leverage, performance and alpha, and grouped by sector, industry, factor and strategy
